Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Is organic matter chemistry or temperature a stronger driver of microbial community structure in permafrost soil?
Award.AbstractNarration:
On earth, carbon cycles through many reservoirs including the atmosphere, plants, soils, rivers, and the ocean. Permafrost (permanently frozen soil) contains almost as much carbon as is stored in plant biomass globally, and is therefore an important carbon reservoir. Climate warming in the Arctic has caused degradation and thaw of permafrost in some locations. The carbon in permafrost is stored in the form of organic materials that are less decomposed than in soils from warmer climates, because decomposition has been stalled under frozen conditions. If these soils thaw, this carbon may be decomposed by microorganisms and released to the atmosphere during their respiration. This would add much more carbon dioxide, as well as methane, to the atmosphere and lead to a positive feedback, where increased carbon concentrations in the air cause increased warming, which causes the release of more permafrost carbon into the atmosphere.

The amount of carbon dioxide and methane that is released to the atmosphere upon permafrost thaw will be a function, in part, of which particular microbial species are present. Metabolic patterns vary among the microbes, and as a consequence so do the quantities and composition of the possible respiratory products, mainly carbon dioxide and methane. Thus, it is important to study the occurance of various microbes and their functioning so that we can predict how they may respond to permafrost thaw. This project will examine how the species of microbes in permafrost are assembled. This has not been studied in the past because these soils are often deep and of course hard, making them difficult to penetrate and sample. Also, recent advances in DNA sequencing methods now allow researchers to ask new questions that were not possible even a few years ago. The results from this project will advance understanding of how changes in the temperature of permafrost soils affects microbes and the carbon cycle. Undergraduate students will participate in the project and be mentored in research skills and laboratory practices. Finally, the results will be made available through publications and more directly to a public audience on the web and in through live presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Permafrost (permanently frozen soil) contains a vast stock of carbon that was removed from the atmosphere by plants that lived tens of thousands of years ago, and has been locked away ever since.  In fact, permafrost soils hold about twice as much carbon as is in the entire atmosphere. In most environments, microbes begin to decompose dead plant material as soon as leaves fall to the ground or roots die.  But decomposition in permafrost has been stalled because of the frozen conditions. After being locked away for thousands of years, this frozen stock of carbon is now vulnerable to decomposition due to climate change induced thawing.  Climate warming in the Arctic has already caused degradation and thaw of permafrost in some locations (and an example of how this looks is shown in the picture). As these soils thaw, this previously frozen carbon can be decomposed by microorganisms and emitted to the atmosphere through microbial respiration in the form of the greenhouse gases carbon dioxide and methane. A large release of greenhouse gasses would accelerate warming, and change climate patterns across the globe.  What happens in the Arctic could affect people everywhere.

 

The amount of carbon dioxide and methane that is released to the atmosphere upon permafrost thaw will depend, in part, on which types of microbes are present. And despite the harsh environment, thousands of different species of bacteria and fungi coexist in these soils. Different species use the carbon in permafrost in different ways, which can affect the rates of greenhouse gas emissions. Thus, it is important to study the microbial communities in permafrost so that we can predict how they may respond to thaw.

 

We know that in most other environments, the forms of microbial food available determines which microbes are present.  But in permafrost, temperature might be more important since only some species can grow under frozen conditions. In this study, my advisors and I (along with the help of an undergraduate student doing a research project) investigated the factors that control which microbes are present in permafrost by giving permafrost microbes two different sources of organic matter to metabolize at two different temperatures. We then determined the similarities and differences in the microbial community structure. This research question has not been investigated in the past because these frozen soils are buried deep, making them difficult to collect. Also, recent advances in DNA sequencing techniques allowed us to ask new questions about microbial communities that were not possible even a few years ago.

 

We found that the composition of the organic matter as well as temperature affected which microbes grew in these permafrost soils, but that temperature was the more important factor. In addition, the amount of carbon dioxide produced through respiration, also depended on both temperature and the chemistry of the organic matter. Thus, we might anticipate that microbial communities will adapt rapidly as permafrost soils thaw and warm in response to both the inundation of newly thawed organic matter and temperature, resulting in communities ideally suited for their new conditions.

 

This research allows scientists to make better predictions about how climate warming and subsequent permafrost thaw will affect microbial communities and the carbon cycle. This is important because better predictions of how the earth system will change enables policymakers, businesses, and individuals to make better informed choices.
